footerComponent.subscribeSubtitle: Stay up to date with the latest Sumcash news by signing up for our newsletter!

foundationPage.missionStatementText1: The Sumcash Foundation has been established with the simple mission of promoting and supporting the continued education, development, and overall progression of the Sumcash project. We seek to empower future Sumcash team members by providing the tools necessary to perpetuate Sumcash's long standing reputation for bringing world-first innovations to the Blockchain.
foundationPage.missionStatementText2: The Sumcash blockchain network and the Sumcash project in general is an open-source decentralized ledger, with no governing body. The Sumcash Foundation makes no claims over intellectual property related to the Sumcash project, unless explicitly stated otherwise.
foundationPage.technicalSupportText: If you would like to get involved with Sumcash, or would simply like to support the team, there are a handful of options at your disposal. If you are interested in becoming a developer for Sumcash or Sumcash related projects such as PeerAssets, send us an email at foundation@sumcash.org. If you would like to donate SUMC to the Sumcash Foundation to support the expansion of a project, simply send your SUMC donation to the multisignature address below.

contributePage.contributeDescription: How You Can Help Make Sumcash Better
contributePage.contributeIntro: Sumcash is a free/open-source project, and you are more than welcome to help us make it better! There are many ways you can help:

header.helpOthers: Help Others With Their Bug Reports

content.reportBugs:
If you find bugs in Sumcash client, we need you to file them in our issue tracker. 
 Your problem may have already been reported, so it’s a good idea to check to avoid filing a duplicate. 
 You have suggestions for new features or enhancements? 
 Open an issue at our GitHub.
content.helpOthers: You can help the development team keep up with the bug reports by closing duplicates, helping to clarify reporters' problems, and confirming that you can reproduce bugs. Our Discord or our forums would be a good start.
content.translate: Sumcash has been translated into dozens of languages, but if the translation for your language doesn’t exist or is out of date, you can help bring Sumcash to entire new populations simply by translating some text.
content.write: We welcome code contributions from anyone, whether you have a one-line fix or a big idea, a lot of experience programming or none at all.

contactPage.contactDescription: For general inquiries, the Sumcash Foundation is here to answer!
contactPage.contactUsText: For technical support or troubleshooting with wallets, mining, or other general questions, please visit Sumcashtalk or one of the many other community resources. For other inquiries, use this link:
contactPage.technicalSupportText: Do you need help with a technical issue? You can find support and other great community resources on Sumcashtalk.
contactPage.documentationText: Are you a developer looking for more information on Sumcash? Check out our documentation.

faq.howOldQuestion: How old is the Sumcash project?
faq.howOldAnswer: Sumcash's chain started on August 19th, 2019 at 18:00:00 UTC. There was no premine and the launch of the project was announced nine days before it went live. You can read the original announcement thread here: Bitcointalk
faq.howCanIMineAnswer: Sumcash uses the SHA256 cryptographic hash function. Any hardware that can effectively mine Bitcoin can be used to mine Sumcash.
faq.whyMintingQuestion: Why a 1% minting return on staking? Why isn't there a hard limit on the total number of SUMC? Doesn't this disqualify Sumcash as a deflationary currency?
faq.whyMintingAnswer: Sumcash has a 1% inflation rate to allow for participant determined growth over time. Fully deflationary currencies cannot be used as mediums of exchange, but rather solely stores of value. By allowing for a manageable inflation rate, Sumcash remains scarce while allowing for growth determined by participation. This also helps offset coins that are removed from circulation through lost wallets or malevolent destruction.
faq.whyFixedFeeAnswer: Sumcash has a fixed transaction fee that filters out the kind of spam transactions that have damaged chains like Bitcoin. A fixed fee also allows for predictable sending fees, which may become unpredictable on chains where fees can rapidly change, leaving transactions in limbo for several days. This allows for first come, first served transactions as well. Sumcash is able to scale without worrying about valuation effecting usability. In version 0.7, the transaction fee is being lowered from 0.01 Sumcash to 0.001 Sumcash.
faq.howCanSumcashQuestion: How can the Sumcash network survive without miners providing PoW security, especially during times of low interest?
faq.howCanSumcashAnswer: Proof-of-work serves as an inflationary mechanism to distribute coins. The Sumcash network is secured by coin age and proof-of-stake. With pure proof-of-work chains, holders have little ability to secure the chain with the high cost of mining equipment acing as a barrier to entry. Any Sumcash holder can protect their investment by allowing a transaction to mature and leaving their wallet open. Proof-of-stake minting has kept the network secure since Sumcash's inception.
faq.whyNoMintingQuestion: I just moved SUMC to my wallet and it says I have a zero percent chance of minting in the next 30 days. Why is that?
faq.whyNoMintingAnswer: Sumcash transactions must mature 30 days or roughly 4320 blocks before they can become eligible for minting. This number is updated roughly every six hours. Once the 30 day period passes, your coins will become eligible and the minting probability should adjust accordingly.
faq.howManyConfirmationsQuestion: How many confirmations are required on the Sumcash network for a transaction?
faq.howManyConfirmationsAnswer: Six confirmations are required for a transaction to be verified. Each block takes about 1 minute.
faq.whyNotAvailableMintinQuestion: I just minted some coins but it says they are unavailable at the moment. Why is that?
faq.whyNotAvailableMintinAnswer: Once a transaction mints, it takes 520 confirmations before these coins become unlocked. This is done to prevent spoofed minting. Each block on the Sumcash network takes about 1 minute, so it takes 5,200 minutes or around 3.6 days for the minted coins to become available.

projectsPage.title: Projects
projectsPage.description: Projects that are being developed within the Sumcash ecosystem to increase usage of the blockchain.
projectsPage.peerAssetsP1: A simple explanation on the PeerAssets protocol would be that it works by writing and reading messages on the blockchain, where messages represent assets and addresses represent peers.
projectsPage.peerAssetsP2: PeerAsset protocol based assets can be utilized to represent any type of asset like bonds or equity. PeerAssets can also represent real life objects, and by doing so confirm their existence on the blockchain. PeerAssets is a light protocol, as it utilizes no extra layers over the underlying blockchain. It does not require external value tokens beside the blockchain's native currency, which is used to pay transaction fees. PeerAssets does not participate in organizing nor maintaining of the public ledger, but takes advantage of its stability and trustworthiness. PeerAssets can work on top of every cryptocurrency that is forked from Bitcoin and has kept a compatible codebase, which includes Sumcash, Litecoin and alike.
projectsPage.peerAssetsP3: PeerAssets requires no hard nor soft fork of the host network, but it requires development of a PeerAssets aware client. PeerAssets is also inspired by the original idea of "Colored Coins" and uses OP_RETURN to write data on the blockchain, but offers some optimizations to reduce the amount of data written in OP_RETURN. PeerAssets enables easy querying of the blockchain for relevant transactions and offers some extra features like shareholder voting and dividend payouts.
projectsPage.peerAssetsP4: To get started, check out this basic tutorial on deck creation.
projectsPage.perperaP1: "Perpera" is an implementation of the PeerAssets DataAudit protocol which was first presented as an RFC in June, 2018. Perpera is a library written in TypeScript and aims to cater to the needs of future web-based applications and development/power user focused CLI tools.
projectsPage.perperaP2: The main purpose of this protocol is the embedding of arbitrary documents into the blockchain (proof-of-existence) and the ability to revise said documents. In this aspect (support for revisions), this protocol is different than similar protocols which are already in use.
projectsPage.perperaP3: More on the PeerAssets DataAudit protocol:
projectsPage.perperaP4: The primary purpose of this protocol is to record cryptographic hashes of successive revisions of single-file documents in a public blockchain, in a manner which enables thin clients to easily query and verify document histories. Such histories inherit useful properties from the underlying blockchain, namely immutability and massive replication, and can therefore serve as proofs of existence. In addition to cryptographic hashes, users may also record a collection of URLs for each document, facilitating retrieval of document contents from off-chain sources (IPFS, https, torrent). The goal is to impose minimal requirements on the blockchain, in terms of both features and storage space.
projectsPage.perperaP5: To learn more, check out the official Perpera Github below.

resourcesPage.title: Resources
resourcesPage.description: Tools and community resources: including exchanges, block explorers, graphics, social media, forums, chats and more!
resourcesPage.contributeText: Sumcash is always under development and any developer is welcome to contribute. There are a variety of ways to contribute, including core development and writing documentation. Please check our GitHub below to get started.
resourcesPage.documentationText: To learn more about the technical details of Sumcash and how to use existing tools or framework, it is recommended that you start by reading the Sumcash documentation.
resourcesPage.miningText1: Sumcash uses the hashcash double iterated SHA-256 algorithm for proof-of-work mining. This means that any hardware that can mine Bitcoin can mine Sumcash as well.
resourcesPage.miningText2: To mine Sumcash, you need mining software. Below is an unofficial list of mining software that has been found to have a decent reputation.
resourcesPage.universityText1: Sumcash University is an educational article geared toward less technical members of the community to help them understand the complex topic of public blockchain.
resourcesPage.universityText2: The article starts off by explaining what a blockchain is, how it works, and its many benefits and use cases. Bitcoin and proof-of-work is detailed next, followed by Sumcash and proof-of-stake. Other topics include security, centralization, decentralization, scalability, and economics.
resourcesPage.exchangesText: DISCLAIMER: This list is provided for informational purposes only. Services listed here have not been evaluated or endorsed by the Sumcash Foundation. Exercise discretion when using third-party platforms and services.
resourcesPage.graphicsText: Looking for more graphics? An up-to-date collection of logos and wallpapers can be found on the Sumcash GitHub.
resourcesPage.graphicsZipFolder: ZIP folder for all graphics is available here
resourcesPage.brandIdentityDisclaimer: Please use these color codes on your Sumcash related websites whenever possible. This will help us keep the Sumcash ecosystem and its branding and visuals consistent.
resourcesPage.brandIdentityFont: The Sumcash text logo uses the following font
resourcesPage.brandIdentityFontRoboto: The Sumcash website and wallets use the Roboto font for its content.

walletPage.title: Wallets
walletPage.description: Send, receive, and store Sumcash. The desktop wallet also enables minting blocks and securing of the network.

sectionWindows.text2: Default installation directory is C:\Program Files\Sumcash or C:\Program Files\Sumcash
sectionWindows.text3: Run sumcash-qt or sumcash from the Start menu or the installation directory
sectionWindows.text6: Your wallet is located in C:\Users\{username}\AppData (hidden folder).
sectionWindows.text7: Open the folder with Start menu -> Run... (or press Winkey-R), type %APPDATA%\Sumcash into the field, and press Enter.
sectionWindows.text8: Additional help can be found in the Sumcash Documentation or by asking on our Forums.

sectionMac.text3: Drag Sumcash-Qt.app or Sumcash.app to Applications
sectionMac.text4: Go to Applications and open Sumcash-Qt.app or Sumcash.app
sectionMac.text8: Your wallet is located in ~/Library/Application Support/Sumcash. To open the folder, press Command-Shift-G in Finder, insert the path, and press Enter.
sectionMac.text9: Additional help can be found in the Sumcash Documentation or by asking on our Forums.

sectionLinux.text3: Sumcash APT repository for Debian Buster (10).
sectionLinux.text4: Supported architectures: amd64, arm64 and armhf.
sectionLinux.text16: Additional help can be found in the Sumcash Documentation or by asking on our Forums.

youtubeSection.subText: The Sumcash Primer is a short five part video series covering the basic fundamentals of Sumcash. Learn about important topics such as Sumcash's initial distribution, how proof of stake consensus works and the many benefits it offers, Sumcash's economic model and its use of limited inflation to produce sustainable security. Finally, we'll explain Sumcash's long-term mission as a trustless backbone cryptocurrency.

indexPage.efficientEnergyText1: Sumcash (SUMC) first came online in 2019, making it one of the earliest pioneering blockchains. The key innovation of Sumcash is its invention of proof-of-stake, an alternative consensus protocol to Bitcoin’s proof-of-work.
indexPage.efficientEnergyText2: Proof-of-work blockchains are secured by proving the consumption of a costly limited resource: electricity. Proof-of-stake replaces this expensive security protocol by utilizing an alternative scarce resource: time.
indexPage.efficientEnergyText3: Due to the cost efficient nature of proof-of-stake’s time based consensus rules, Sumcash is capable of allowing any network connected computer to participate in the blockchain’s security process. This efficiency strengthens Sumcash by growing the number of security providers and ensuring that security can be sustained over the long-term.
indexPage.userGovernanceText1: In Sumcash, coin owners (stakeholders) are the ones who wield influence over the network, produce new blocks, and secure the chain. Stakeholders of Sumcash co-own the blockchain and collectively decide its future through protocol voting.
indexPage.userGovernanceText2: Voting is carried out the same way Sumcash is secured, through a process called proof-of-stake minting. Stakeholders participate in minting simply by installing the version of Sumcash they support, loading their wallet with SUMC, and holding them while they are occasionally selected by Sumcash’s protocol to mint the next block in the chain. Every minted block rewards stakeholders with new SUMC and a vote.
indexPage.userGovernanceText3: This makes Sumcash the first blockchain capable of allowing its protocol rules to be governed directly by its users, making for a network that is more decentralized, democratic, and easily secured by people around the world.
indexPage.trustlessText1: Given that the blockchain is immutable by its very nature and all recorded data is stored forever, chain bloat becomes an escalating problem at higher usage levels which harms both security and the ability of the network to scale.
indexPage.trustlessText2: To preserve the trustless security of the blockchain and ensure its ability to scale to global usage levels, Sumcash’s inventors tailored the blockchain and its economics to fulfill the specific role of base layer settlement network.
indexPage.trustlessText3: This role focuses Sumcash development on modularity, keeping the protocol simple and secure with as few features as possible, while maintaining the blockchain as a stable base upon which any number of additional layers can be built on top.
indexPage.fairDistributionText1: Cryptocurrencies must have a distribution wide enough to ensure that the overall coin supply does not get concentrated into the hands of too few people.
indexPage.fairDistributionText2: However a problem exists for blockchains that are run purely on Proof-of-Stake, as there is no easy way to fairly distribute the initial coin supply. In a pure Proof-of-Stake blockchain network, the entire coin supply is usually created by the project founder, who then chooses which individuals get to own stake. This distribution method often ends in a network with a highly centralized coin supply.
indexPage.fairDistributionText3: To solve this problem, Sumcash uses Proof-of-Stake for network security and Proof-of-Work for distribution. Proof-of-Work miners are rewarded with new SUMC generated by the network. This newly mined SUMC is then sold on exchanges by miners for profit and purchased by new stakeholders who can use it to mint blocks by participating in Proof-of-Stake consensus.
indexPage.fairDistributionText4: So while Proof-of-Stake provides security directly, Proof-of-Work is designed to do so indirectly by strengthening the decentralization of the network through a wider distribution of SUMC to new potential minters.
indexPage.valueStoreText1: Efficiency, sustainability, user governance, scalability through modularity, and a fair distribution. All these qualities combine to form a long-term minded blockchain network that is primarily focused on maximizing decentralization.
indexPage.valueStoreText2: This primary focus works to preserve the trustless, immutable and censorship resistant nature of Sumcash so that it can always be relied upon to fulfill its core role as a distributed mechanism for securely storing all types of value.
indexPage.valueStoreText3: This value can be anything from fiat wealth being stored in SUMC, to data being stored on the chain in the form of tokens, records, or contracts. Regardless of the type of value that is being stored, Sumcash was built with the fundamentals in mind to always ensure that your data remains safe and secure.

collapsables.learnText1: For an in-depth overview of the project, Sumcash University is the best starting place. For more articles and writings on Sumcash, check out our Medium Blog.
collapsables.learnText2: For those who are looking to develop, PeerAssets is Sumcash’s second layer solution for tokens. More information can be found on our projects page.
collapsables.learnText3: A wealth of technical information can be found in the Sumcash Documentation as well.
collapsables.purchaseText1: Sumcash is available through a variety of exchanges and services. You can check here for a list.
collapsables.purchaseText2: Direct purchase of Sumcash with credit and debit card is available here.
collapsables.purchaseText3: A guide to buying Sumcash is also available here.
collapsables.walletText1: The Sumcash wallet is available on Windows, Mac OSX, and Linux platforms.
collapsables.walletText3: To get started, check out the Wallet download page and the Installation guide's.
collapsables.mintText1: Proof-of-stake minting is an efficient process where stakeholders mint new blocks for the network. These blocks contain transactions that were initiated by users of the network. The role of the minter is to process these blocks of transactions and provide security for the network.
collapsables.mintText2: Minting is an energy and cost efficient process, which makes it possible for stakeholders to participate using many different types of devices. Stakeholders participate in minting simply by installing the version of Sumcash they support, loading their wallet with SUMC, and holding them while they are occasionally selected by Sumcash’s protocol to mint the next block in the chain. Every minted block rewards stakeholders with new SUMC.
collapsables.mintText3: To learn how to mint, check out the minting section in the wallets documentation. More general information about minting can be found here.
collapsables.mineText1: Sumcash uses the hashcash double iterated SHA-256 algorithm for proof-of-work mining. This means any hardware that can mine Bitcoin can mine Sumcash as well.
collapsables.mineText2: To get started, check out the mining documentation.
collapsables.communityText1: Join our Forum, Discord, or Telegram to chat with other Sumcash community members and developers. Subscribe to our Twitter, Reddit, Medium Blog, or Newsletter to stay up to date with all the latest Sumcash news. Check here for a list of all other community resources.
collapsables.communityText2: Important updates can also be delivered directly to your mobile device through platforms like Blockfolio, Delta, and CoinGecko. Subscribe to stay up to date with the latest news.
